thread.title: Tech giants drive Nasdaq to record high
thread.title_full: Tech giants drive Nasdaq to record high

title: Tech giants drive Nasdaq to record high
text:
Netflix chief executive Reed Hastings remains humble about Netflix's success, despite having 65 million members. Photo: Supplied
US technology stocks are back in demand after three of the sector's bluest chips announced stellar results, pushing Wall Street's Nasdaq index up to a record high.
As Australia's bank- and mining-dominated exchange muddled through a modest Friday with the ASX200 trading around 5660 points, three technology companies yet to reach 20 years of age pushed the Nasdaq composite up by 1.26 per cent on Thursday to finish at 5163.18 points.
We do our best to remind ourselves that we are really quite puny compared to all television viewing.
Reed Hastings, Netflix Video streaming service Netflix, e-commerce giant eBay and internet search and advertising behemoth Google all delivered strong results, sending sentiment soaring across US exchanges.
"It just proves the US market continues to be resilient in the face of what seems like an endless list of global worries," Longbow Asset Management chief executive Jake Dollarhideâ€‹ told Reuters.
Video streaming and production company Netflix's stocks have more than doubled this year as it launched its global expansion. The service launched in Australia in March 2015.
Although the company report a 63 per cent drop in net profits, its results this week rocketed its shares up 18 per cent, mostly because of excitement around its strong user acquisition numbers, which saw the company pick up 3.3 million new users in just three months.
The tech index as hit a record high.
Netflix, which now touts a $42.5 billion market capitalisation, was listed in 2002 as a DVD rental service before switching focus to online video streaming.
Chief executive Reed Hastings explained the profit slump and user growth by focusing US reporters on the company prioritising user growth over profitability.
"We remind ourselves that we've only got 65 million members, and there are billions of people in the world watching television. We have such a long way to go, and we do our best to remind ourselves that we are really quite puny compared to all television viewing," Mr Hastings told The New York Times .
"Users now and profit later" has become something of a mantra for venture-backed technology startups such as Facebook, Amazon, Uber and Google.
Google's shares surged 13.5 per cent on the back of expectation quarterly results that beat analyst expectations with both higher revenue and tighter cost management.
The 17-year-old company began its rise on handmade servers has now passed $US400 billion ($540 billion) in market capitalisation with its shares passing $US674. The company has listed 11 years ago in 2004 it had a market capitalisation of a record-breaking $US23 billion.
Ecommerce giant eBay also beat analyst forecasts for its second quarter with its total company revenue coming in at $US4.68 billion, above expectations of $US4.49 billion.
The US exchanges also benefited from the announcement by the European Central Bank it would increase emergency liquidity for Greek banks, as well as positive homebuilder sentiment and employment data this month.
More traditional companies such as Citigroup and Goldman Sachs also reported better than forecast results for 2015 second quarter.
